monumentInformation.title: Who Built It
details: India Gate was designed by British architect Sir Edwin Lutyens, known for his role in designing New Delhi.
It was commissioned by the British government as a memorial to honour Indian soldiers who died during World War I.

monumentInformation.title: Where It Is Located
details: India Gate is located in the heart of New Delhi, on the eastern end of the ceremonial avenue called Rajpath (now Kartavya Path).
It stands as a central point in the city�s layout, surrounded by lush green lawns and public spaces frequented by visitors.

monumentInformation.title: When It Was Built
details: Construction of India Gate began in 1921, during the colonial period when New Delhi was being developed as the capital of British India.
The monument was completed in 1931, taking 10 years to build and becoming a prominent landmark in the newly established city.

monumentInformation.title: How Is It Protected By
details: India Gate is maintained by the Indian Army, which is responsible for guarding and preserving the structure and its surrounding area.
The monument is also under the care of the Central Public Works Department (CPWD), which ensures its maintenance and upkeep as part of New Delhi�s national heritage.

monumentInformation.title: Why It Was Built
details: India Gate was built as a war memorial to commemorate the 84,000 Indian soldiers who died during World War I and in other conflicts under British rule.
It serves as a symbol of sacrifice and valour, and today, the eternal flame of the Amar Jawan Jyoti beneath it honours soldiers who died in later conflicts like the Indo-Pakistan War of 1971.
